div.l: Toward the mille and bayard on hond
The millere bi the fier / sittyng he fond
For it was nyht / and / and / and ferther myht they nouht
But for the love of god / they hym bisouht
For herbergh and ese / as for ther peny
The miller seyde a geyn / yf ther be any
Such as it is / yit shul ye have yoᵘur part
Myn hous is streit // but ye have lerned art
Ye kan bi argumentis / make a place
A myle brood / of twenty feet of space
Lat se now / if this place may suffice
Or make it rommer / with speche as is your guyse
Now Symond seyde Iohn / bi seynt Cuthberd
Aay is thow mery / that this is wel Answerd
I have herd sayd / me shal take of twa thynges
Such as he fynt / or take such as he brynges
But specially / I pray the hoost deere
Get vs sıı̄um mete / ⁊and drynk / ⁊and make vs cheere
And we wol payen / trewly at the fulle
With empty hond / men may noon hawkis tulle
Loo heer our siluer / Al redy for to spende
This miller to the toun̄ / his douhtir sende
For ale and breed / and rosted hem a goos
And bond her hors / it shuld no mor͗e go loos
And in his owne chaıı̄umber he maad a bed
With sheetis and with chaloıı̄uns / wel I spred
Nat from his owne bed / ten feet or twelue
His douhtir hadde / a bed bi hir selve
Riht in the same chambir / bi and bi
It myhte be no bet / and cause whi
Ther was no rommer / herbergh in the place
They soupen / ⁊and they spekyn hem to solace
And drynken ouer strong ale / at the beste
Aboute mydnyth / went they to reste
Wel hath this miller / vernysshed his hede
Ful pale he was for dronkyn ⁊and nat rede
He yexeth and speketh / thoruh the nose
